review.title: Iterative Aggregation Method for Solving Principal Component Analysis Problems
review.abstract: Motivated by the previously developed multilevel aggregation method for solving structural analysis problems a novel two-level aggregation approach for efficient iterative solution of Principal Component Analysis (PCA) problems is proposed. The course aggregation model of the original covariance matrix is used in the iterative solution of the eigenvalue problem by a power iterations method. The method is tested on several data sets consisting of large number of text documents.

sections.text: Keywords: main component analysis, cluster method, power iteration method, aggregation method, eigenvalue problem

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: This paper was conceived as an application of the multi-stage aggregation method [1] applied by the author to PCA problems in the 1990s. Multi-stage aggregation method was an extension of well-known multigride methods [2] from limit problems to general structural analysis problems, which brought them into the class of algebraic multigride methods.The idea of the aggregation method was to use some naturally constructed course models of the original finite element approximation of a structure that provides rapid convergence for iterative methods for solving large algebraic equation systems.One of the applications of this method was an iterative solution of large eigenvalue problems that occurred in structural natural vibration and buckling analyses.In these problems, a sought-after group of lowest vibration modes can be considered as the main components of structural behavior. An obvious similarity to PCA was a turning point in the search for a suitable aggregation model for data matrix and its use.
